title: 'Confusion, anxiety': Expats from one country urged to check citizenship status
text:
An "unconstitutional"﻿ law that stripped citizenship from South African dual nationals has been reversed – and the implications have sent a ripple of confusion and alarm throughout the expat community.

The South African Citizenship Act (Act 88 of 1995) previously required South Africans to seek ministerial permission to retain their citizenship before becoming citizens of another country, including Australia.

Anyone who failed to do so would lose their citizenship – until now.

South Africans who became citizens of another country without ministerial permission after 1995 automatically lost their SA citizenship. (Getty)

Citizenship restoration is now in full swing after a court ruled this provision was unconstitutional and invalid in May 2025.

It is not automatic and eligible expats need to use the reinstatement portal.

It only applies to those who have lost their citizenship on or after 6 October 1995, according to the South African High Commission.

There were 214,790 South African-born people living in Australia as of 2023, according to the Australian Department of Home Affairs.

READ MORE: Residents in fear after teenagers invited to planned mass bike rideout in Sydney

What is the dual citizenship law in South Africa?

Reinstated citizens – including those who retained their citizenship prior to the rule change – are required to enter and exit South Africa using a South African passport﻿, a rule similar to the ETA scheme soon coming into effect in Britain.

This has been the entry and exit requirement in South Africa since 2004.﻿

It may impact thousands﻿ of Australian-South African dual citizens who wish to resume their citizenship after their SA passports expired.

The Australian government's Smartraveller advice﻿ states that "if you hold Australian-South African dual nationality, by law you must enter and exit on your South African passport".

"We recommend all possible dual nationals consult the South African Department of Home Affairs website to verify your citizenship status," Smartraveller noted.

The SA High Commission also states the same on its website.﻿

Most other visitors, including those from Australia, the US, UK, Canada and New Zealand, don't need a visa for tourist or business stays under 90 days.

Hayley Reichert, a South African-born expat and advocate living in London, initiated the "Loss of Citizenship Campaign" in 2014, which eventually led to last year's court ruling.

Reichert told nine.com.au there is now "significant confusion" around South African expats hoping to return home on foreign passports after the resumption of their citizenship.

Hayley Reichert is a passionate advocate for South Africans living abroad. (Supplied)

She runs a voluntary initiative supporting South Africans abroad named Operation Watershed and has been working to help expats with this constitutional change.

"Many now fear the issuance of fines, detention, refusal of travel, and even the threat of imprisonment," Reichert said.

"This climate of anxiety is disproportionate to the actual legal and practical reality."

What happens if my South African passport has expired?

The law states that citizens must have a valid South African passport or proof of renunciation of citizenship to enter or exit.

However, Reichert has called for calm among expats.

She said South African border control has a "degree of institutional understanding" over the challenges now faced by dual nationals.

﻿There may not be blanket punitive enforcement of this rule, she explained.

"In theory, repeat non-compliance can result in fines or prosecution (up to 12 months' imprisonment), but in practice this is extremely rare," Reichert said.

"Most individuals resolve their documentation after a first warning."

The Embassy of the Republic of South Africa said the department acknowledges that many dual citizens may not be aware of the amendment to the act and the implications for their travel.

"We have therefore decided that affected South Africans departing or arriving through our ports of entry, attempting to use a foreign passport, will be issued with a warning giving them three months to obtain a South African passport," it stated in a notice.

"They will be allowed to depart or enter South Africa."

You don't need a visa if you're visiting South Africa for tourism purposes for up to 90 days. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"In many cases, travellers receive a formal warning and stamp in their foreign passport noting that South African citizens are not permitted to enter or exit on foreign passports and are instructed to regularise their South African documents," Reichert added.

Reichert encouraged South Africans living abroad﻿ to do their research and contact the relevant authorities before booking or cancelling trips over this entry requirement.

She said dual citizens had a responsibility to comply with the law ﻿– but called for calm amid "confusion, anxiety and misinformation".

Can Australian-born children get South African citizenship?

The SA High Commission states that a child born outside of South Africa to at least one parent with South African citizenship has a claim to citizenship by descent.

They must register the birth in South Africa to obtain citizenship.

title: Dragging Melbourne roadworks threaten to put locals out of jobs
text:
Exclusive: When Rebekah Becsi spoke to A Current Affair last year, she was terrified that roadworks might send her out of business.

Now she's told 9news.com.au she's just weeks away from being forced to shut down.

And help﻿ – if it ever comes – might just be too little, too late.

READ MORE: Urgent safety warning issued over counterfeit melatonin sleep supplements

Rebekah Becsi owns Pakenham Bulk Foods, a discount bulk grocery store about an hour out of Melbourne CBD. (Supplied)

﻿Becsi runs Pakenham Bulk Foods on Bald Hill Road﻿ in Pakenham, about an hour southeast of Melbourne's CBD.﻿

Sales plummeted when Big Build Victoria roadworks blocked off half the road in February last year.

They took another hit when the whole road was blocked a few months later.

"We've had a total 80 per cent decrease in sales from February last year till now," Becsi told 9news.com.au.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

The roadworks, which were supposed to finish by the end of 2025, are expected to drag out until the end of February and Becsi's business won't survive that long.

She doubts it will even last another month.﻿

"We need immediate assistance, otherwise we will not last until the end of February," Becsi said.

"And I know there's other businesses in the area that are in the same boat as us."

The roadworks outside Becsi's Pakenham business have caused an 80 per cent drop in sales. (Supplied)

The roadworks and road closures have made it too hard for customers to reach stores like ﻿Pakenham Bulk Foods, so most just go elsewhere.

It's left Becsi unable to afford new stock and struggling to cover crucial costs.﻿

"We're only just paying rent now, we don't have any spare money," she said.

She and a number of local businesses are also ﻿allegedly being chased for council rate payments they can't afford.

Becsi and other Bald Hill locals ﻿spoke to A Current Affair last year about the devastating impacts the roadworks had had on their businesses.

They had hoped the segment would help them get compensation from Big Build Victoria or Cardinia Shire Council for lost revenue.

It's been weeks since the segment aired. They're still waiting.﻿

"We're getting no kind of relief or support," Becsi said.

This map shows the convoluted path customers need to follow to get to Pakenham Bulk Foods while the roadworks are ongoing. (Facebook/Pakenham Bulk Foods)

Cardinia Shire Council Mayor Councillor Brett Owen told 9news.com.au that while council is not a delivery partner on the roadworks project, he recognises local business owners' frustrations.

"On behalf of our community and businesses, Council has continued to advocate to the State Government to manage and minimise construction disruptions and ensure access is maintained to reduce impacts wherever possible," he said.

A Big Build Roads spokesperson told 9news.com.au, "we appreciate the community's patience while the get on with more than $1 billion in upgrades to road and rail infrastructure in the area.

"We will continue to provide support to local traders during construction."

They said the Pakenham roads upgrade will be complete in mid-2026 with the intersection near Pakenham Bulk Foods set to reopen in late February.

But ﻿Becsi's business may not survive that long.

By the time these signs are cleared and the road reopens, Becsi's Pakenham business may be shut down. (Supplied)

Without immediate financial support, she will have to cut her losses and close ﻿Pakenham Bulk Foods.

Becsi worries about what will happen to the handful of customers who are still relying on the discount store for affordable groceries.

"You've got people who are struggling with the cost of petrol and groceries in the general supermarkets, and they'll come to us," she said.

"Even if we do close down, something has to be done about it."

Becsi started a Change.org petition demanding financial support in the form of compensation for loss of revenue, grants, or low-interest loans for businesses affected by the roadworks until they're complete.

More than ﻿800 people have signed.

Dragging Melbourne roadworks threaten to put locals out of jobs as businesses face closure. (Supplied)

But if Becsi wants to take the issue to the Parliament of Victoria - which is her hope - she'll need to create an official paper petition or digital e-Petition.

A paper petition needs more than 2000 signatures to trigger a debate in Parliament; an e-petition (alone or alongside a paper petition) needs 10,000.

And none of the Change.org signatures will carry over.

title: MP 'beyond angry' over death of brother in alleged one-punch attack
text:
After 12 years in politics and countless media interviews, today marked Chris Picton's toughest exchange.

The South Australian health minister spoke publicly for the first time since his brother Tim Picton died from an alleged one-punch attack in Perth last month.

"Beyond angry as to what's happened," Chris said of the incident.

READ MORE: More human remains and clothes found in search for missing Belgian tourist

The South Australian health minister spoke publicly for the first time since his brother Tim Picton died, following an alleged one-punch attack in Perth last month. (9News)

"The shock that we had on that Saturday morning, getting that phone call, still haunts me and my family to this day."

Tim, 36, died in hospital after a three-week-long coma following the incident.

"It was unlikely that Tim was going to come back, but we were still obviously all hoping for a miracle," Chris said.

The 20-year-old charged over the incident has been granted bail, angering the MP.

"I cannot believe that that happened and I think that was a very significant mistake," Chris said.

Tim, who made a name for himself in Labor's ranks as a talented political strategist, had a bright future ahead.

Tim Picton, 36, died in hospital after a three-week-long coma following the alleged attack. (Supplied)

"The prime minister said he very easily, at the very least, could have been on the frontbench of federal parliament, and I strongly believe that," Chris said.

He is survived by his wife Priya and their four-year-old daughter Charlotte.

At a memorial for Tim last week, guests were asked to write their memories of Tim for Charlotte to read when she's older.

"There's a hole in our family that is never, ever going to be filled," Chris said.

Prime minister and two premiers among hundreds at memorial for Labor figure Tim Picton (9News)

As for Chris, he tells 9News that despite the heartache, he's committed to returning to state parliament should he be re-elected in March and wants to continue serving in the ministry.

"Going through some difficult personal experiences hopefully can make you a better representative, a better leader," Chris said.

"This is not the sort of thing that you get over, it's the sort of thing that eventually you learn to live with."

title: Queen Mary and King Frederik announce official visit to Australia
text:
Queen Mary and King Frederik of Denmark are set to visit Australia in March for an anticipated six-day tour.

During the visit from March 14 to 19, the couple will attend a number of business and cultural engagements.

This will be their fourth official visit to Australia and their first since the King's ascension to the Danish throne.

Q﻿ueen Mary and King Frederik of Denmark are set to visit Australia in March for an anticipated six-day tour. (WireImage)

In a statement tonight, the palace said: "The state visit will further develop the already strong relations between Australia and Denmark, both culturally, economically and in foreign policy.

"A strengthened partnership with Australia is particularly important at a time when geopolitical upheavals have economic and security policy consequences that bind developments in Europe and the Indo-Pacific region together.

"Building on the strategic partnership that was entered into between Australia and Denmark in 2023, the state visit will strengthen cooperation in a wide range of areas, including green transition and economic security."

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he felt honoured to welcome the royals to Australia.

"It is wonderful that the visit includes many parts of our great country, from the Northern Territory to Victoria, the Australian Capital Territory, and of course Tasmania," he said.

"Denmark and Australia are great friends, and together we are working to build a more sustainable, secure and peaceful future.

"This visit is an opportunity to deepen our cooperation across a number of shared interests such as sustainability, renewable energy and innovation.

"Their Majesties The King and Queen of Denmark have a very special connection with Australia, and I know Australians will welcome them."

title: University campus to be split between housing and open space
text:
About half of Adelaide University's Magill campus will be sold for housing, retirement living or aged care under a plan announced by South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas.

The campus was part of the old University of South Australia but was not needed by the new-merged university in the long-term.

Three hectares of land east of St Bernards Road stand to be sold from next year.

Mr Malinauskas said at least 20 of the 100 blocks planned for sale would be earmarked for affordable homes.

"As a government, we want to see homes being built, particularly at an affordable price point, so that young families in the eastern suburbs of Adelaide also have a chance to raise their kids in the eastern suburbs," Mr Malinauskas said.

"So that's why you've got to be willing to pursue a balance which is what we've arrived at today."

Premier Peter Malinauskas with Magill Matters members at today's announcement. (ABC News: Thomas Kelsall)

Merger led to sale

The state government's land management agency Renewal SA bought the 15-hectare site for $64 million in 2023 as part of the deal that led to the merger of UniSA and the University of Adelaide to form Adelaide University last month.

Adelaide University has a lease on the buildings on western part of the site that ends in 2033–2034.

The area around the historic Murray House and Third Creek will be retained for open space, while retirement units and aged care facilities up to five storeys high will be built on the rest of the site.

Adelaide University's Magill campus is on both the west and east side of St Bernards Road. (Supplied: Renewal SA)

The campus sits on the boundary of two marginal Liberal-held electorates: Morialta, held by retiring MP John Gardner, and Hartley, held by former opposition leader Vincent Tarzia.

Liberal leader Ashton Hurn said Mr Gardner and Mr Tarzia's lobbying had led to more open space being announced than previously proposed.

"I think it's really important that we preserve these sites for community use," Ms Hurn said.

She criticised the government for not opening consultation until April, after the March 21 state election.

"Voters will need to wait until after the election to get a real crystal clear understanding of what the government plans to do," she said.

A map showing the land to be retained (green) and sold (pink) at Adelaide University's Magill campus. (Supplied: SA government)

Win for community group

The plan was completed in consultation with a community group called Magill Matters, which had planned a petition-signing event for Sunday afternoon.

"We're really excited for our community for this outcome — really excited," Denise MacGregor from the group said.

"It is about finding a balance and it's about keeping our green space."

Flanked by Labor's candidates for Hartley and Morialta, Mr Malinauskas said not developing housing on the campus would lead to higher house prices.

"The easiest thing to do politically in these circumstances is to say 'we're going to retain it all for green space and there won't be a home to be built'," he said.

"But when you do that project after project after project, guess what happens? You get a housing supply crisis and that's what we've seen too much of."

title: Inside the brand strategy behind the Beckham family drama
text:
When Brooklyn Beckham chose Instagram to air his grievances amid reports of a rift within the Beckham family, it was easy to dismiss the move as impulsive.

But crisis and reputation experts say the decision — and the British family's response — points to a far more calculated approach to managing public fallout in the age of social media.

"Everything about it is strategic," Susan Grantham, a reputation management expert at Griffith University, said.

"This isn't a 26-year-old randomly deciding to post something. It's been orchestrated to contribute to a specific narrative," Dr Grantham said.

"Nothing goes out on social media, particularly when you're part of a very famous family, without it being checked over and thought through."

Brooklyn Beckham claimed his parents had tried to "ruin" his relationship with his now wife, Nicola Peltz Beckham. (Reuters: Aude Guerrucci)

Brooklyn — the eldest son of ex-professional footballer Sir David Beckham and former Spice Girls member Lady Victoria Beckham — posted to Instagram Stories last week saying he did not want to reconcile with his family.

He accused his parents of being "controlling" and claimed they had tried to "ruin" his relationship with his now wife, American actress Nicola Peltz Beckham.

The message, shared in a format that disappears after 24 hours, quickly spread beyond social media through screenshots and reposts.

According to US-based crisis communications strategist Molly McPherson, who hosts the PR Breakdown podcast, that amplification was no accident.

"Brooklyn Beckham is piercing his family with an arrow," she said.

"Everybody is going to his Stories and clicking on him and following him — so now he's getting the engagement."

The episode, experts say, shows how younger generations are increasingly shaping crisis narratives on their own terms — and often before traditional media can frame them.

Stories, not statements

Dr Grantham says Brooklyn's decision to speak directly to followers rather than through a spokesperson reflects a fundamental shift in how crises now unfold.

"We're in a unique moment where different generations expect to be communicated with in different ways," she said.

"Youth audiences expect correspondence through social media, so responding in the same environment where the drama is occurring is now standard practice."

Brooklyn Beckham took to Instagram to reveal he does not want to reconcile with his family. (Instagram @brooklynpeltzbeckham)

By choosing Instagram Stories — a format that disappears within a day — Brooklyn was also shaping how long the messaging was intended to live.

"There's exclusivity to the content," Dr Grantham said. "His obvious intention was for this to go live and disappear. I've had my word and that's it."

While the posts were quickly screen-recorded and shared elsewhere, she said the temporary nature of the format still carried symbolic weight.

"It told a very specific story — that he wanted to say something once and only once, which I think made it more intriguing."

Ms McPherson said the timing of the posts — just before Sir David attended the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland — was also likely deliberate.

"I think Brooklyn knew precisely where his father was, and that his father would be ambushed on this."

Saying something without saying anything

Days later, Sir David was asked at the World Economic Forum about parenting in the age of social media, offering an indirect answer that avoided addressing the family dispute head-on.

"Children are allowed to make mistakes, that's how they learn. So that's what I try to teach my kids," he said during a broader discussion on a CNBC panel.

"But you know, you have to sometimes let them make those mistakes as well."

Sir David Beckham avoided addressing the family dispute head-on. (AP Photo: Markus Schreiber)

Ms McPherson believes the exchange was carefully managed.

"There is no doubt in my mind that the Beckham team, their PR handlers, worked with CNBC and there was a deal made," she said.

"The deal made was this: David will sit down and do this interview with you, but you have to serve him this opener."

Dr Grantham said Sir David's oblique approach was deliberate.

"It's a technique where you embed a particular story into an existing narrative, but allow others to make sense of it in the way they wish," she said.

"He obviously wanted to say something, but didn't want to say anything. Given the question he was asked, he handled it reasonably well."

She said carefully chosen language allowed audiences to draw their own conclusions — without the risk that came with explicit engagement.

" He said particular words that allowed people to make connections that maybe didn't explicitly exist. "

Both experts said the episode highlighted a generational split in how the Beckham family managed public narratives.

"We've seen the first move out of the gate was throw Brooklyn under the bus," McPherson said.

"We're going to give [his parents] a little bit of leeway here because they became big global brands during the 90s when the tabloid media culture was brutal."

A billion-dollar brand under scrutiny

The Beckham brand is reportedly worth close to $1 billion. (Reuters: Gonzalo Fuentes)

Among the most damaging claims, Brooklyn accused his mother of hijacking his first dance with his wife at their wedding.

"She danced very inappropriately on me in front of everyone," he said in one of the posts.

"I've never felt more uncomfortable or humiliated in my entire life."

The family dispute has played out against the backdrop of the Beckham name as a global brand spanning football, fashion, beauty and media — reportedly worth close to $1 billion.

Despite the headlines, Dr Grantham said large, established brands were often far more resilient to this kind of internal dispute than might be expected.

"Bizarrely, they're not heavily affected," she said.

" The bigger the brand, the more likely something like this draws attention rather than destroys it. "

Unlike smaller organisations, which can suffer reputational collapse in a matter of hours, she says high-profile brands can absorb controversy.

"Something like this is creating intrigue more than huge negativity," she said.

"There's the memes, the humour, the 'he said, she said'. All of that keeps people engaged."

Experts say the feud has driven further engagement with the Beckham brand. (Instagram: @memes)

She points to companies like Samsung — which survived the crisis of exploding phones — as an example of how scale and effective narrative management can blunt reputational damage.

"If you're a big enough brand and you handle the crisis well enough, people continue to engage with the story rather than abandon the brand."

That engagement has taken unexpected forms, with a solo single Lady Victoria released more than two decades ago briefly topping the UK and Ireland iTunes charts after resurfacing online during the controversy.

Strategic silence

While others — including a DJ and social media users — continued to fuel speculation about the feud, the Beckham family itself largely stepped back.

That, Dr Grantham said, may be the most revealing part of the strategy.

"They really haven't done a lot to create any further narrative. They've taken a step back and just allowed the story to live," she said.

Are celebrity family rifts validating or potentially damaging? Celebrity family rifts are not new. Experts weigh in on how they can spark negative feelings about our own family dynamics.

For now, Dr Grantham believes that restraint is working.

"If the story became excessively negative, that's where crisis managers would step in and advise them to address it differently. But right now, it's not doing them any damage."

Ms McPherson said the Beckham brand would "100 per cent" survive but argued Sir David and Lady Victoria may need to lean more heavily into their individual identities.

"If they were working with me, I would have said something to the effect of: 'We love our son but like all families, we've made mistakes, and we don't want to cash in on his pain.'

"That's what they need to do. But will they do it? I don't know."

The broader lesson is clear: in modern crises, control doesn't always come from speaking louder — but from knowing when, where and how briefly to speak at all.

title: Darwin council coffers 'not at all' impacted by high-rise spend, mayor says
text:
The City of Darwin's new lord mayor says construction of the council's new civic centre will not affect funding of other major projects or ongoing Cyclone Fina clean-up efforts, despite community concerns.

Construction is continuing on the new Darwin Civic Centre development, a $150 million, 21-storey public-private development planned for the CBD, after beginning late last year.

The building will be part-owned by property developer DCOH, which is responsible for its design and construction through an early contractor involvement process with the council.

Darwin's new Civic Centre is currently under construction. (Supplied)

But the project has faced criticism from local residents and the Australian Institute of Architects, which have raised concerns about the building's "scale and intensity" and a lack of cohesion with other buildings in the area.

Councillor Julie Fraser said constituents had raised "legitimate concerns" about the pressure the high-rise investment was placing on the council's finances.

"People want reassurance about what this means for other priorities such as local infrastructure, climate resilience and community services," she said.

Darwin Lord Mayor Peter Styles, who was elected to the role in August, said that despite holding concerns about council's investment in the building before the election, those had been resolved since he took office.

"I've had a good look at it, I've been thoroughly briefed on it, and it's a great project for the City of Darwin," he said.

"[The] council has got value for money — in fact, probably a better deal than a lot of others around town have got, so we're very pleased with what I've seen and most councillors are all very happy."

Peter Styles says the council has got "value for money" in the build of the new Darwin Civic Centre. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

In 2021, the City of Darwin committed $30 million to the redevelopment of its civic centre building, and in 2024 its budget was increased to $78.5 million as part of the council's 2030 municipal plan.

According to the council's latest financial figures from December, the council has spent $19.5 million on the project since its consultation phase in 2022, with about $11 million of that spent in the past year.

The project's current budget stands at $77.6 million, with an additional $2 million set aside for "project contingency" costs.

Construction is underway in the CBD as the Darwin Civic Centre project progresses. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Cr Styles said council spending on other projects, including the as-yet-undisclosed cost of the Cyclone Fina clean-up, would "not at all" be impacted by the civic centre outlay.

"Money allocated to [the civic centre redevelopment] comes from various sources within council, and also from the approval of the territory government, so that's all covered," he said.

" The council still has a budget for other capital works. "

Among other projects the council has budgeted for in 2025-26 is $10 million for the expansion of the Darwin tip and $3 million for a recreation space in the city's northern suburbs.

Developments, Construction, Operations and Hospitality (DCOH) is working to deliver the Darwin CBD project. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Lease negotiations underway for the CBD's 'Paris End'

DCOH chief operations officer Lachlan Michell said construction of the civic centre building was expected to be completed in 2028, with levels 15 and 16 set to be in place by January 2027.

He said the installation of a Lubeca Jumpform system at the worksite had marked a major milestone.

"[It's] a hydraulic jacking system that will constantly progress up the building until you get to level 21. That's where the lift core and the stairs are," he said.

Lachlan Michell says DCOH is working to secure tenants for the upper floors of the building. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Once completed, DCOH will own the upper 10 floors of the building, which Mr Michell said the company planned to lease out as office space.

"We're actively working with potential tenants on that, we've got leasing proposals out for I think five floors at the moment, and there's some really strong interest, not just locally but interstate," he said.

Since 2025, the building's leasing agent NTC Property has been advertising about 11,000 square metres of available space on the civic centre's upper floors, which it describes as "positioned in the prestigious eastern precinct of the CBD, often referred to as the 'Paris End'".

An NTC Property representative declined to provide a price range for the leases, but said the company was "hoping to achieve premium rents".

The new Darwin Civic Centre will scale 21 storeys and is expected to be completed by 2028. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Mr Michell said the project remained on schedule despite last year's Cyclone Fina, wet season conditions and the serious injury of a worker at the construction site last month.

The incident, in which a 50-year-old worker suffered an injury to his arm after being struck by a falling excavator bucket, led to NT WorkSafe issuing a safety alert.

Mr Michell said DCOH had notified NT WorkSafe within minutes of the incident and was cooperating with the regulator.

"We're pleased to report [the worker] is doing well; he got some medical treatment and is working through that, he's in good spirits and we're working with the subcontractor to make sure he returns to work," he said.

Current council chambers to be demolished

The City of Darwin has confirmed that its current council chambers will be either fully or partly demolished after the new civic centre is built, with chief executive Simone Saunders saying that was "always part of the process".

She said consultations to be held this year would inform what happened to the site once the current chambers were demolished, emphasising the need to preserve a 100-year-old Banyan tree in the building's courtyard.

Simone Saunders says the new build is an exciting development for Darwin. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Ms Saunders said 400 square metres of the new civic centre's lower floors had been earmarked for "community-commercial" spaces.

"That might be some arts and cultural [organisations], and also some commercial organisations that also need a small retail footprint" she said.

"Community wants to see more spaces where they can gather for meetings and have discussions, and maybe even pop-up art installations."

title: Moments of calm and chaos — WA in January, captured in pictures
text:
In the first month of 2026, our photo journalists captured many special moments across Western Australia.

From the heatwaves and bushfires that swept the state down to the "Sea Shell Teabaggers" trying to keep cool in the city.

But they've also been on the scene to witness tragedy and serious news events that will have long-lasting repercussions.

Here are the best photos that illustrated the story of WA in January 2026.

Horizon ball

The Horizon Ball on Geraldton's foreshore is a popular place to watch the sunset. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Every evening, a crowd builds to watch the sunset over the ocean through a unique sculpture in Geraldton.

The image has been popular online, including on Chinese social media, and has been drawing international visitors only in Australia for a matter of days, to the coastal city.

Fire in the suburbs

Helicopter water bombing at Ellenbrook fire near Perth on January 29th, 2026. (ABC News: Bridget McArthur)

When a bushfire took hold right in the middle of the tightly-packed suburb of Ellenbrook, mayhem ensued on the ground.

In the air, however, the calm and precise efforts of water-bomber pilots managed to tame the hysteria.

Pinball collection

Azza Williamson is a pinball enthusiast. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Inside what appears to be a backyard shed in Albany, a collection of pinball machines from across the world is erupting with flashing lights and sounds.

Inspired by his teenage years, Greg Sharp has 50 pinball titles in his impressive collection.

Red all over

Christmas Island's red crabs have developed a unique ecological role over tens of thousands of years. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Christmas Island's red crabs are on the move again.

The sight of a massive, semi-translucent red carpet of crabs marching from the sea has local residents breathing sighs of relief.

Once they reach their destination, it will take four to five years for the crabs to reach adulthood.

Sailing into Freo

The winning Great Britain sail GP vessel. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)

Fremantle hosted the international Sail Grand Prix for the first time this month, a Formula 1-style sailing event that saw 13 international teams skimming the water's surface at high speeds in front of a crowd of thousands.

Reigning champions Great Britain raced to the finish line, beating the Australian team which claimed second place.

'Sea Shells Teabaggers'

Shelley Taylor-Smith runs free swimming lessons at Mettams Beach. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

For the past year, retired seven-time World Marathon Swimming Champion Shelley Taylor-Smith has been running free swimming lessons at Perth's Mettams Pool, helping mature women overcome their fear of the ocean and build confidence in the water.

Some are stepping out of their comfort zone and training to take part in the Busselton Jetty Swim later this year, armed with goggles and special swim caps.

The group call themselves the "Sea Shells Teabaggers".

Sweltering heat

Neil Munro at Marble Bar's look out. (ABC News: Kimberley Putland)

It is said there are three certainties in life — death, taxes and Marble Bar being hot.

Residents in parts of WA's north sweltered through heatwave conditions in January, including Neil Munro, who recorded temperatures of more than 50 degrees Celsius in the town on his digital weather station.

Mr Munro's assessment: "It's not very pleasant."

Extraordinary ceramics

Two sets from Drysdale's Breakaway series IV - Elephant Rocks (front) and Wolf Creek Crater (back), made in 2025. (ABC News: Emma Wynne)

The unstoppable creativity of ceramicist Pippin Drysdale is on full display in this striking photo.

Her works are collected around the world, but she has never been featured in her hometown’s state gallery.

The first retrospective of the ceramic artist's work has gone on show in Perth at the state gallery, telling the story of an extraordinary career.

Return of Fringe

Performers gather for the opening of Perth's 2026 Fringe Festival. (ABC News: Lauren Smith)

Perth's Fringe World Festival is underway, with organisers expecting half a million people to flock to shows over the next month.

It's the third largest fringe in the world, behind Edinburgh and Adelaide, and it has kickstarted Perth's festival season.

Around 3,000 performers are involved in more than 600 shows including the Ladyboys of Bangkok, pictured above.

Fresh paint

The mural painted adheres to the theme 'Strong Spirits, Strong Minds.' (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

A new mural from Perth artist Hope adorns Karratha's town centre.

Featuring local siblings Miyah, 8, and Yuriah, 18-months-old, it's part of a new government-sponsored campaign called 'Strong Spirits, Strong Minds.'

"I hope all the First Nations people in the community feel proud about it and kind of connect with the moment that the mural's representing," Hope said.

Invasion Day rally

Perth's Invasion Day rally was interrupted by a bomb threat. (ABC New: Cason Ho)

On January 26, an Invasion Day rally in Forrest Place was interrupted by a man who allegedly threw an improvised explosive device into the crowd.

Chaos and confusion ensued when police took charge and dispersed the crowd, captured in this single frame.

The event, which is now being investigated as a potential terror threat, is likely to cast a long shadow over the rest of the year.

Light show on the Swan

People film the fireworks show along the Swan River on the evening of Australia Day. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

People gather on the banks of the Swan River to watch the Australia Day fireworks. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

Meanwhile, on the banks of the Swan River, the Australia Day light show rolled on as usual, with thousands turning out to watch the fireworks.

title: Alcaraz, Djokovic meet in Australian Open battle of generational greats
text:
Like Roman soldiers, tennis gladiators Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic are vowing no surrender after setting up an Australian Open final for the ages.

Separated by 16 years in age but sharing the same unbreakable will, wizardry skills and desire, Alcaraz and Djokovic are fighting for a special place in the sporting record books tonight.

Rod Laver Arena will be the two combatants' colosseum as 22-year-old Alcaraz strives to become the youngest man to complete a fabled career grand slam and Djokovic, at almost 39, bids for an unprecedented 25th singles major.

The stakes could not be higher.

Novak Djokovic found the energy to beat Jannik Sinner in five sets. (Getty Images: Darrian Traynor)

"Obviously for Carlos, because of his age and everything that he was able to achieve so far, history is on the line for both of us every time we play," Djokovic said after winding back the clock and ending the title defence of two-time champion Jannik Sinner at almost 2:00am yesterday.

"The finals of a grand slam, you know, there's a lot at stake, but it's no different from any other big match that I play.

"My preparation is as it should be, and I won against him last year here, also in a gruelling (quarter-final) match. Let's see. Let's see how fresh are we both able to be."

Djokovic hits out at critics Novak Djokovic sets his sights on those who doubted whether he could still be an Australian Open contender.

Djokovic needed four hours and nine minutes to see Sinner off, saving 16 of 18 break points in what may have been the finest clutch display of the super Serb's incomparable career.

The seismic victory took an immeasurable physical and mental toll, with Djokovic offering "no predictions" of how his body will recover.

But, driven by the doubters, the former world number one is only promising one last stand in pursuit of the exclamation mark to the most decorated CV in men's tennis history.

"He also had a big match, but he has 15, 16 years on me," Djokovic said of Alcaraz's own five-hour, 27-minute five-set semi-final triumph earlier on Friday over Alexander Zverev.

"Biologically, it's going to be a bit easier for him to recover. But, yeah, I look forward to it.

"Look, I play tennis competitively mainly to be able to reach the finals of grand slams. Here I am, so I cannot complain about anything."

Already a six-time time major winner, boasting two titles each from Wimbledon and the French and US Opens, Alcaraz is contesting his first final at Melbourne Park.

Djokovic is playing his 11th on Rod Laver Arena, his personal battle ground where no man has conquered the Serb in a title match and where Rafael Nadal, Andy Murray, Dominic Thiem, Daniil Medvedev, Stefanos Tsitsipas and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga have all fallen on their swords trying.

Carlos Alcaraz was titanic in overcoming Alexander Zverev in the semifinals. (Getty Images: Darrian Traynor)

Alcaraz, though, shapes as the Melbourne Park king's fiercest challenger yet, having already dethroned Djokovic at Wimbledon and shown in fighting through cramps to deny Zverev that he does not know when or how to yield.

"I just hate giving up. Just how I could feel after all. I just don't want to feel that way," the indomitable Spaniard said after battling back from 5-3 down in the deciding set against the German third seed.

Alcaraz prevails in ultimate match of margins The margins can prove to be razor-thin when it comes to the business end of grand slam tournaments. Carlos Alcaraz and Alexander Zverev found out firsthand in an all-time classic.

"There are some moments that it seems like, 'OK, I'm just giving up or just I'm not fighting at all', which, when I was younger, there were a lot of matches that I just didn't want to fight anymore or just I gave up.

"Then I just got mature, and I just hate that feeling after all.

"(Now I'm) thinking I could do it or I could do a little bit more or I could suffer a little bit more, that feeling of just kill myself.

"Every step more, every just one second more of suffering, one second more of fighting is always worth it.

"So that's why I just fight until the last ball and always believe that I can come back in every situation."

On age and form, Alcaraz is the favourite.

But he was the fancy at Roland Garros too in 2024 when Djokovic defied the experts to complete the golden slam with an against-the-odds Olympics final triumph on the Paris clay against the reigning French Open champ.

Now Alcaraz, the current world number one, is in Djokovic's house trying to add the final piece of his own storied slam.

Both want it bad, but only one can prevail.

"I would choose this one," Alcaraz said of the trophy he craves most.

"Yeah, if I make the final of the other three, I would say I would rather win this one than the three and complete the grand slam and be the youngest ever to do it."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Every old home tells a story. Here's how to find yours
text:
On a cold Ballarat winter's day, Billy Harraway-Jones decided to uncover the story of his family home.

What he found was a saga of courtship and marriage in a new world, and of life and death on the Australian goldfields.

Mr Harraway-Jones had at his disposal an internet connection and patience.

With access to online databases and local council records, he slowly pieced together a history of the house.

The tools are there for anyone to use.

Billy Harraway-Jones opened the door on his family home's history. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

"I grew up in my parents' house in Lydiard Street, and you always knew that, even though you think of it as your house from your perspective as a kid, many of those houses in that street are over 100 years old," he said.

"There's been multiple different people cycle through that house.

" The weather had been miserable and, I thought, 'I've got a bit of time, why not do something different, and find out about those people?' "

Mr Harraway-Jones had been told the home's first owner was William John Payne.

It turned out it was William's father-in-law, Cornish immigrant Philip Williams, and that the metaphorical "ghosts" of the house were older than he suspected.

William courted and married Elizabeth Williams, then aged 18, in August 1866, and eventually moved in.

Before long, Mr Harraway-Jones found himself scanning marriage certificates from Cornwall and delving into a family history 17,000 kilometres away.

Billy Harroway-Jones says local historical societies can offer further insights. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

Intriguing tales

There are grand old buildings across Australia with great histories and many proverbial ghosts to be discovered.

However, even comparatively modest places have an intriguing tale to tell, Gippsland historian Linda Barraclough said.

Historical ownership records exist even for abandoned properties. (Supplied: Greg Davis, Explored Visions)

"Houses do not have to be big and grand to be worth researching," Ms Barraclough said.

"Sometimes the humblest tell the more interesting stories.

"They do not even have to be that old."

Ms Barraclough said good examples were houses used immediately following World War II.

"The worker housing immediately after the Second World War, like the Australian Paper Manufacturing houses in Traralgon, prefabricated railway houses in Traralgon, SEC houses in Yallourn and in Newborough," she said.

"They were called 'snail houses' because one SEC executive said if workers are going to be recruited [from the United Kingdom], they were going to have to bring their homes with them. Even sawmilling houses can have fascinating histories."

Treasure trove of history

You don't need to be a professional historian to begin tracing your old house's history.

Mr Harraway-Jones's first steps towards discovering the deeper history of his home were made on Trove, an online database owned by the National Library of Australia that catalogues Australian newspapers, government archives, library records and museum documents and manuscripts.

The National Library of Australia's Trove research portal can be searched online. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

"Just going through Trove, reading [old newspaper] articles, there wasn't too much, but what you do is you find a bit of a trail," Mr Harraway-Jones said.

"You may potentially find a birth or death notice, for example, and that's enough to start putting the pieces together and working out your next source."

Ms Barraclough described Trove as "a game changer".

While libraries had extensive records in bound volumes or microfiche (microfilm), Trove enabled near-instant searches of names, places and even keywords that may appear in news articles or other documents.

"There's a high percentage of newspapers that you can read online back to their beginnings and the brilliant thing is they're searchable," Ms Barraclough said.

"It's not only newspapers. It's got a lot of maps, it's got a lot of books and a huge cache of photographs, and it's just changed research completely.

"You can sit at home and do it on your computer."

A 1939 sewerage map from the Maffra Sugarbeet Museum collection. (Supplied: Maffra Sugarbeet Museum)

Tracking down the title

Another good place to start is the property's title history, which can be accessed online through Land Registry Services in NSW or Landata in Victoria.

A title history search statement lists the names of current and previous owners, dates of sale and mortgage discharge information.

A property's title history report can be obtained from each state's land registry service. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

Mr Harraway-Jones said those basics could then be used to expand a search within a local area or parish.

"You can then start searching things like council documents," Mr Harraway-Jones said.

"We've got really good digitalised rates records in the Ballarat Library or you can view them online.

" That can tell you a lot about who lived there. You get their surname, occupation, whether or not they just owned it and rented it out or if they lived in it, and then you start putting a picture together. "

Once armed with these essentials, Ms Barraclough said local historical societies and clubs, and even groups on social media could help colour in the details of what life was like for past owners and residents.

The history of old Australian homes can be accessed online. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

Detours and dead ends

Mr Harraway-Jones said there were a few hiccups along the way.

The property had several street number changes over its history, which had to be navigated through council records before he was able to lock down an address.

However, having sketched out a timeline of the house's history, he said he was confident he could do it for any old house in Australia — and that anyone else with sufficient diligence and tenacity could too.

Mr Harraway-Jones said his home had seen many ups and downs over its 146-year history.

"My father used to joke, 'This house is so old, someone's probably died here,'" he said.

"This all confirmed what my dad used to say. Multiple people died there, but at least a few were born as well."

Billy Harraway-Jones used Trove to help discover details about his home. (ABC News: Gavin McGrath)

Where to search:

If you're looking to research your home, here are a few places you might start:

title: 'Brave' 12yo shark attack victim honoured with paddle-out at North Bondi
text:
Hundreds of paddle boarders, friends and family have journeyed into the waves of North Bondi to pay tribute to 12-year-old shark victim Nico Antic.

Nico's dad (right), Juan Pablo, is also a volunteer life saver at North Bondi. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

The paddle-out this morning was organised by his school, Rose Bay Secondary College, which said he would be remembered as a "happy, vibrant, and social young person".

Twelve-year-old Nico Antic was attacked by a shark and left critically injured west of Shark Beach on Sunday, January 19. (Facebook: Rose Bay Secondary College)

The boy was attacked by a shark after jumping off rocks west of Shark Beach at Nielsen Park in Vaucluse on Sunday, January 18.

Authorities believe a bull shark was responsible for the bite that caused critical injuries to the North Bondi surf lifesaving nipper's legs.

People gathered on the shore before the paddle-out. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

Almost a week later, his parents Lorena and Juan released a statement saying their son had died from his injuries at Sydney Children's Hospital in Randwick.

Hundreds turned out for the paddle-out tribute. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

The community came together on the shore, then formed a circle in the ocean.

At one point there was a large round of applause and cheering from the water.

'A brave, gritty little kid'

An aerial view of the paddle-out. (Supplied)

Nico's father Juan Pablo also spoke after the paddle-out and referred to his son as "our Nico", saying that he would be forever remembered.

Easts Junior Beasties rugby club president Graham Jackson said it was "pretty emotional".

Mr Jackson says Nico was "brave". (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

"When Nico's dad was out speaking, there was an awful lot of love and respect around the place for that family and you could really feel that out there," he said.

"It's touched the whole community."

There were some emotional scenes. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

Mr Jackson said a lot of people who knew Nico and his family through the rugby and surf lifesaving clubs turned up to pay tribute.

"If you speak to anyone at the rugby club, or at his school, the word that comes out is 'brave or bravery' time and time again," he said.

"He was a brave, gritty little kid and he's remembered for that quality more than anything else."

Some people watched from the pathway. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

Isobel, Eddy and Jocelyn went to the same school as Nico.

Isobel said it was great to see the community come out to honour him.

"We saw a lot of our teachers, a lot of our classmates, and I recognised a few people from the club,” she said.

“I’ve seen heaps of things with his friends saying how great of a person he is and how that story is being shared which is amazing, that’s the best thing to come out of all of this.”

Jocelyn, Isobel (centre) and Eddy went to the same school as Nico. (ABC News)

Eddy said there was a sense of “togetherness” during the paddle-out, with “splashing, clapping and cheering”.

“I’ve heard a lot of stories of how great a person he was and what he did for people, and he put others before him and I think he deserved this,” he said.

Jocelyn said it was a “peaceful” event for a “great student”.

Martin Broglia said the paddle-out was all about community and connection.

"It was a farewell for Nico and just saying goodbye to him and supporting his family," he said.

" [He was a] fun guy, always playing, always doing lots of sports, always with his father, with his friends. "

Ed and Eleanor say there was a "community" feel to the paddle-out. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

Ed Shand and Eleanor Lott also came out to pay tribute.

"It was good to see everyone come together as a community and show that everyone cared and showed their support," Ms Lott said.

"I think the big show out really proved the good side of humanity and how everyone comes together in times like this. I think it was really, really nice," Mr Shand said.

" I think it shows he'll be remembered for a long time. "

People consoled and hugged each other. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

The North Bondi Surf Life Saving Club released a statement after Nico died, saying he arrived at nippers every week with a "big smile and wonderful" attitude, and would be "deeply missed".

"He was easy-going, independent, and a true lion heart — determined, with a genuine love for all sports and the kinship they brought," it said.

"He wholeheartedly loved the ocean and simply loved being at Nippers.

"Last year, he was recognised with a Nippers award, a reflection of the lion-heart spirit, enthusiasm and kindness he brought to our club."

title: Workers at iconic WA tourism hotspot say they're being exploited and underpaid
text:
A growing number of workers at several Ningaloo Reef tour operators say they were underpaid and overworked in the seasonal roles that prop up the tourist hotspot.

As companies recruit new staff ahead of the peak winter months, some workers are calling for an investigation into the closely knit industry worth tens of millions of dollars.

Among them is Keelan Priscott, who said six months in his one-time "dream job" had left "a sour taste".

Keelan Priscott holds a master's degree in marine biology and was eager to work on the world's largest fringing reef. (Supplied)

"I was one of two applicants selected out of 160 applicants for diving," the 27-year-old said.

"After leaving the UK three years ago, I could have never imagined that I would have landed a role up in the Ningaloo."

The remote WA town of Exmouth, about 1,230 kilometres north of Perth, attracts tens of thousands of visitors each year as the chief gateway to the World Heritage-listed Ningaloo Reef.

The tourist town of Exmouth in WA's north-west. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Its kaleidoscopic corals and marine animals are fixtures of state and federal advertising campaigns, contributing $110 million to the state's economy annually, according to Tourism WA.

But Mr Priscott said he was paid "far below the minimum wage" and missed out on about $4,000, plus superannuation, during his time as a dive instructor.

"It's really a cash cow," he said.

His former employer, Dive Ningaloo, denies the allegations of underpayment.

In a letter to the ABC, the company said it was not aware of any wrongdoing, and was "extremely disappointed that [Mr Priscott] did not raise the matter" before leaving Exmouth.

Legal questions

Central to Mr Priscott's claims is the legal distinction between independent contractors and employees.

Independent contractors often negotiate their own fees and arrangements, such as working for multiple clients.

They do not have the same rights as employees and forego casual loading, overtime, superannuation and worker's compensation.

Keelan Priscott took his pay dispute to the Fair Work Ombudsman, but says progress has stalled. (Supplied)

Since August 2024, the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO) has set out a "whole of relationship test" to help employers determine whether a worker is a contractor or an employee.

Mr Priscott claims he was wrongly treated by Dive Ningaloo as a contractor, when he was legally entitled to the benefits of a casual employee.

How did we investigate these allegations? Reviewed Keelan Priscott's first contract, payslips and invoices.

Obtained text messages between Mr Priscott and Dive Ningaloo management.

Spoke with multiple sources about work practices in Exmouth's marine tourism industry.

His first contract, signed in January 2025 and seen by the ABC, showed he was being paid a flat rate of $220 for an 8-hour day on Ningaloo Reef.

A rate of $240 was paid for a 9-to-10 hour day at the Murion Islands.

Under the professional diving industry (recreational) award for casual employees in FY2025, he would have received a minimum rate of $32.49 an hour, or $259.92 for an eight-hour day.

During FY2026, that figure rose to $33.71 an hour.

Company rejects claims

Mr Priscott has lodged a complaint with the ombudsman in a bid to recoup the thousands of dollars he believes he was underpaid during six months of work.

The regulator declined to comment.

Ultimately, the question of whether Mr Priscott is entitled to the claimed payment will hinge on whether he should have been classified as an employee – rather than a contractor – from the time he began working for them.

The Fair Work Ombudsman declined to comment on the matter. (ABC News: Billy Cooper)

In response to questions by the ABC, Dive Ningaloo said its instructors often began as contractors and were converted to casual employee status within three months.

By July 2025, Mr Priscott too was onboarded as a casual employee and his superannuation paid from then on.

The company said it initially engaged staff as contractors, so staff could claim tax benefits they would otherwise not qualify for.

Workers typically relocated to Exmouth, provided much of their own dive equipment, and paid their PADI dive certification and insurance: all of which the company said they could claim as tax deductions.

"If [Dive Ningaloo starts] people on as a casual and they are not suitable for the job and are dismissed within a week or so, then they have wasted a lot of money relocating," the company said.

" This is done to benefit the worker. "

But Mr Priscott said little changed after he was made a casual employee.

While he did receive superannuation payments from this time, he was still required to invoice the company to be paid.

His wage remained a flat rate per day that was below the minimum award payment he was entitled to as an employee.

He said he did not feel comfortable raising these concerns with Dive Ningaloo because the owner was his landlord in a cash-only rental agreement – something the company acknowledged as "subsidised" housing.

Keelan Priscott says he did not raise the issue because he feared losing his housing. (Supplied/Canva)

Former dean of The University of Sydney Law School Joellen Riley Munton said an examination of whose business was being served was "fundamental" when distinguishing an employee from a contractor.

"Are they [the worker] running their own business or are they working in the business and for the business of a hirer?" she said.

Joellen Riley Munton is one of Australia's leading experts in employment law. (ABC News: Adam Griffiths)

Dr Riley Munton said, in her opinion, Mr Priscott's contract bore several hallmarks of the latter, despite the fact it referred to him as a contractor.

The document asked he be available at fixed start and finish times, purchase and wear a Dive Ningaloo uniform, and not take work at other companies.

"One judge in our system many years ago said you can't decide to call a rooster a duck and thereby turn it into a duck," Dr Riley Munton said.

"If it's a rooster, it's a rooster, no matter what label you give it.

"It seems that a lot of people who are employing people in these areas, are small businesses themselves, and they're not well advised."

The Ningaloo Reef attracts tens of thousands of tourists each year. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Dive Ningaloo said it was willing to discuss the claim with Mr Priscott and had contacted the FWO to initiate a pay dispute resolution, which has not progressed.

"It's been an emotional toll because you feel that the work you're doing is amazing, but the reward you're getting doesn't reflect that," Mr Priscott said.

"It's like the wild, wild west."

Staff allege they were underpaid, overworked

Other workers in Exmouth have come forward with allegations of underpayment at multiple companies, including some of those behind its famous whale shark experiences.

At least five people told the ABC they had enquired with the FWO about different whale shark tour operators, but no further action had materialised.

Only 15 commercial operators are granted licences by the WA government to take tourists swimming with the docile megafauna.

Tours can cost more than $600 per person in some cases.

The remote town of Exmouth contributes more than $100 million to the WA economy. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

One whale shark guide and photographer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said she worked 10 to 12 hours a day for $250, despite being a casual employee.

"We were never offered any extra compensation for longer days or even public holidays or weekends," she said.

She also described a heavy physical toll.

"You get a very mixed type of clientele … who may have never snorkelled before, aren't confident in the water, and you're often doing it in very open ocean, in very rough conditions," she said.

" More than once, I've pretty much saved people's lives. "

One former whale shark guide says she had to save lives on the job, but struggled with underpayment. (Supplied)

She said she was asked to supply and insure her own camera equipment at a cost exceeding $20,000.

Editing clients' photos often saw her work late for no additional pay.

"For a lot of us that work in the industry up here, we're willing to just shoulder that lack of rights, because we do love our jobs," she said.

"But at the end of the day, when you look back on how much money you’re making, how much stress you're under, how long your days [are], it's just not sustainable, it's not affordable.

" And, at some point, you definitely do feel like you've been taken advantage of. "

'Systemic' problems

Filmmaker Nate Porter said he was shocked by the "systemic" issues impacting marine tourism workers when he first arrived in Exmouth.

Nate Porter says he was shocked by the treatment of workers. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

"Everybody up here feels very replaceable," he said.

"Can’t speak out, can’t speak your mind … [or] you're replaced next week."

The problem compounds an extremely high cost of living in the community.

"These whale sharkers that are up here are not living the glamorous life," Mr Porter said.

"I've seen where you've got honestly, like 10 to 12 whale shark employees living in the same house … I've heard people paying as much as $400 a week in rent to live in a trailer in front of the house."

Joel O'Brien says some workers reported being underpaid as much as $10 an hour. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

He took the issue to the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), which has begun its own investigation into several operators.

MUA north west organiser Joel O'Brien said he had contacted Dive Ningaloo late last year to request a copy of Mr Priscott's employment records under a provision of the Fair Work Act.

The company did not respond within the allotted 14-day period, calling the union's correspondence "threatening and belligerent".

Mr O'Brien said more workers had approached the union, with some paid as much as $10 an hour less than they were entitled to under the marine tourism award

"A lot of these people are foreign workers, migrant workers on visas, so they're really open to exploitation," he said.

Know more? Email Alistair Bates on bates.alistair@abc.net.au or securely on alistairbates@proton.me

Having recently relocated to New Zealand, Mr Priscott said his correspondence with the FWO was cut short because the regulator would not contact him overseas.

He plans to return to Australia to pursue the matter.

"The owners just want to reap as much reward from it as possible," he said.

title: Timbertown living museum closes after almost half a century
text:
It was a holiday high point and school excursion for thousands for almost 50 years, but last week, heritage theme park Timbertown closed its doors.

Located in Wauchope, on the New South Wales mid-north coast, Timbertown provided a glimpse of what life was like for Australia's colonial-era pioneers of the timber industry.

The park opened to the public in 1976, and for almost five decades featured a working steam sawmill, bullock teams, a blacksmith, a colonial-era general store, schoolhouse and the crowd favourite, a traditional steam-powered train.

Timbertown gave visitors a glimpse of life in the early timber cutting days, including carting logs with bullocks. (ABC News: Emma Siossian)

In December, owner David Waite announced the park would close its doors in the new year.

The finite opportunity to see or revisit the living museum saw numbers through Timbertown's door surge right up until the end.

"It's been 500 per cent busier since Boxing Day, every single day and it's not quietened down," he said.

Timbertown has been the main attraction in Wauchope for the past 49 years. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

Timbertown's last visitors

People arrived from near and far this week for Timbertown's last day, including Sue Murphy, who travelled from Nowra on the NSW south coast.

Sue Murphy drove five and a half hours to go to Timbertown on its last day. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

"I've always wanted to come here," she said.

"[The closure is] so sad, I couldn't believe it, it's a great place."

Lake Cathie resident Frances Till had a short drive to Timbertown, where she wanted to make one last visit to add to her fond memories of taking her family there in the early 2000s.

Frances Till has fond memories of taking her family to Timbertown. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

"You used to have the bushrangers going out and holding up the train … all the kids wanted to go and do everything," she said.

"My eldest son loved Thomas the Tank Engine and he called the station manager the Fat Controller; he wasn't too impressed."

The steam locomotive was the main attraction for train enthusiast Alex Albans, who travelled from Newcastle for one last experience of Timbertown.

Alex Albans was a big fan of Timbertown. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

"It's not just the steam train I came up for though, it's the heritage of the place and everything else.

"I love everything about the place, you've got the heritage, you've got the history of the timber cutting and of course the gold panning."

Good memories

Mr Waite took over Timbertown in 2010 after the park faced financial struggles and was put up for sale.

He moved his life and family from Marsden Park in Sydney's north-west to Wauchope to carry on Timbertown's legacy.

Timbertown featured a working steam-powered sawmill, a fire station, traditional general store and school house. (ABC Rural)

The decision to close was a difficult one, but one tied to family and years of working seven days a week.

"It was never a financial decision," Mr Waite said.

"I want more family time. I've got beautiful grandchildren now, I want to have Christmas off, Easter off, I want to see them on the weekend."

Mr Waite said he walked away with fond memories.

"I'm overwhelmed this holiday with the amount of people who have come up and shaken my hand and said, 'Thanks for what you've done for 16 years.'

"A lady this morning put $50 in my pocket and said, 'Make sure you have a few beers on me tonight'; the wife has been sent flowers several times over the last few weeks."

The steam train ride has been the main attraction at the heritage park over the past decade. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

Timbertown was renowned as a school excursion destination for generations of children from as far afield as Sydney, Newcastle, Tamworth and Tweed Heads.

"Quite often you'd get school kids come in a little bit disinterested, but then they start doing gold panning and they find a little gemstone and they'd leave here super excited," Mr Waite said.

" I really will miss that. "

Uncertain future

A campaign to sell the park via expressions of interest last year was unsuccessful.

An auction of more than 10,000 items from the park, including the locomotives, will be held in May, with hopes the site will eventually find a buyer.

"All the interest so far has been in the land only, not in Timbertown or its assets," Mr Waite said.

title: Four recipes to help solve your lunch box problems
text:
As kids head back into their classrooms for term one, the problem of how to fill lunch boxes re-emerges.

We've put together some recipes that could help that lunch box come home empty.

Cheese and Vegemite scrolls will be a welcome addition to lunch boxes. (ABC News: Hetty Lui McKinnon)

A classic for a reason, Hetty Lui Mckinnon's iteration of the cheese and Vegemite scroll is likely to be a lunch-box hit.

You can also use the dough and customise the filling to better suit your child's preferences or go with what you have to hand. Sweet fillings (such as cinnamon sugar or jam) or savoury alternatives (such as pesto, tomato and mozzarella or spinach and feta) can also work here.

Sign up to the ABC Lifestyle newsletter Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

These muesli bars are a mighty satisfying snack that are "big batch" friendly.

Perfect for a weekend bake, the recipe relies on ingredients (including seeds, oats and honey) that you might already have in the pantry. Just remember to wait for them to cool completely (1-2 hours) before slicing.

These bars do contain almond butter, so please consider consulting your school's allergy risk minimisation strategy to determine if they are suitable to pack.

You can also opt to switch the almond butter for hulled tahini. (ABC News: Heidi Sze)

This spanakopita rolls and chickpea salad recipe can become a delicious dinner, but any leftover rolls make for a just as delicious lunch box addition.

The rolls can be eaten alone with tomato sauce (as you would a traditional sausage roll) and are equally satisfying at room temperature.

You could have Sunday dinner and Monday's lunch box sorted almost at once.

You can use frozen spinach if you prefer, and add feta, ricotta or parmesan for extra cheesiness. (ABC News: Hetty Lui McKinnon)

Another savoury option for the sandwich averse, these fritters can also help you cook your way out of a zucchini glut.

Frozen peas or corn can be added, as well as a teaspoon of curry powder, za'atar, or some smoky paprika for extra flavour.

This recipe is also gluten free, dairy free and egg free, so can be useful if you have specific dietary requirements to consider.

title: 'Not a house, it's a home': Public housing tenants' human rights breached
text:
An ACT Supreme Court judge quoted Roman philosopher Cicero and the movie The Castle as she ruled in favour of three Canberra public housing tenants who claimed plans to move them breached their human rights.

The three women filed a civil claim after being targeted by a new public housing policy.

The program, called the ACT Growing and Renewing Public Housing Program, had the objective of creating more public housing in the territory, either by using the money from the sale of existing properties or by redevelopment of those sites.

Ultimately, the women were not forced to move.

'Interference with one's home must be lawful'

But Justice Verity McWilliam found that during the process, they were denied procedural fairness, and their human rights were breached.

In delivering her verdict Justice Verity McWilliam quoted Michael Caton as Darryl Kerrigan (left) from the 1997 Australian film The Castle. (Roadshow Entertainment)

"It need hardly be said that any interference with one's home must be lawful. That pithy one-liner in The Castle (1997), voiced in the fictional character of Darryl Kerrigan, still resonates:

"It's not a house, it's a home. A man's home is his castle … You can't just walk in and steal our homes," Justice McWilliam said, quoting the movie.

The judge did note the reference was to a section of the constitution, rather than ACT law, but said: "Expressions of a person's connection to their home stem back to at least Roman times, when Cicero wrote, 'What more sacred, what more strongly guarded by every holy feeling, than a man's own home?'"

The notices to move came in 2020 and 2022.

Commissioner concedes procedural fairness denied

Resolving the case was made easier when the ACT Social Housing Commissioner conceded there had been a denial of procedural fairness in the initial decisions to include the dwellings in the program.

Justice McWilliam noted there was no consultation at the time.

"The policy suggests that such consideration of the potential impact in that regard was to occur at a later stage in the process of required relocation," Justice McWilliam said.

As an example she cited a letter sent to the son of the first complainant:

Dear [son of first complainant] , Please see below decision points: The redevelopment yield for this property will be 3x 2-bedroom properties, There is a low percentage of stock in that suburb, The plans for DA have been lodged and are awaiting approvals. Thanks for your time, [signed]

"There was manifestly no consideration of the first plaintiff's right to freedom from unlawful or arbitrary interference with her home," Justice McWilliam said.

" There was no consideration of the plaintiff's particular circumstances at all. "

But even though the Commissioner for Social Housing did concede there was no procedural fairness, it did fight the breach of human rights claim.

Under the ACT's Human Rights Act public authorities must act in a way compatible with human rights.

The women didn't win on all counts, but did secure a finding their human rights were breached by the actions.

The court has now ordered their costs be paid by the commissioner.

And all are safely in their homes.

'Tense years taken their toll'

One of the women affected, Yvette Van Loo, said the judgment had been a great relief.

"The tense last five years since ACT Housing have tried to remove me have taken their toll in my life and on my health," Ms Van Loo said.

"But what I really want to add is that this situation should never have been allowed to arise. People in charge should be capable, well-educated, and simply do their job".

The solicitor who represented the group, Sangeeta Sharmin, said the outcome sent a message to government officials that they had to give genuine human rights consideration in decision-making.

"Our clients should never have been met with the level of resistance and disregard shown by ACT Housing in the context of a program that was, from its inception, deeply flawed," Ms Sharmin said.

She said the judgment set a precedent, "acknowledging that our clients' houses are not mere assets, but homes — places of identity, community, and cultural connection."
